question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}.\end{align*}\\\\ Find the critical numbers of \emph{y} =
$f(x)$.
sols:
Critical points (numbers) are roots of the derivative. Let's compute
this derivative:

\begin{align*}f'(x) = \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5}\end{align*}

And now find the roots:

\begin{align*}\frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5} = 0\end{align*} We can divide by 6/5

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^{-4/5} = - x^{1/5}\end{align*} Now, clearly \emph{x} = 0 is a solution. To find
possibly others, we now assume that \emph{x} isn't zero and now multiply
by \emph{x}\textsuperscript{4/5}

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1 = - x\end{align*} And obtain a second solution. So we can conclude that there
are two critical points: \emph{x} = 0 and \emph{x} = -1.

Critical points (numbers) are roots of the derivative. Let's compute
this derivative:

\begin{align*}f'(x) = \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5}\end{align*}

And now we can do a little algebra on the function and rewrite as

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5} \\
&= \frac{6}{5} x^{1/5} (x^{-1} + 1)\end{align*}

And so the critical points are solutions of either

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^{1/5} = 0 \quad \iff \quad x=0\end{align*} or

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^{-1}+1 = 0 \quad \iff \quad x=-1\end{align*} And so we have two critical points:
\emph{x} = 0 and \emph{x} = -1.
